options.label: C

title: How to manage your emotions

multiple-choice.question: According to the Process Model, what is the first step in the process that forms our emotions?

options.label: B
options.text: We enter a situation, real or imagined, and that draws our attention.

options.label: C
options.text: We experience a set of changes in how we feel, think, and behave, known as an emotional response.

options.label: D
options.text: We try to regulate our emotions using various strategies.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Shifting our attention away from the stimulus

options.label: C
options.text: Modifying the situation to make it less emotionally charged

options.text: Avoiding the situation altogether

options.label: D

options.text: Going for a long walk or taking slow, deep breaths

options.label: C
options.text: Talking with someone in our support system

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: For being a skilled debater

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: Wearing a sanbenito, a garment marking them as sinners

options.label: B
options.text: They are instantly bent or blown out, resulting in permanent hearing damage.

options.label: C
options.text: They start to vibrate more rapidly, causing temporary hearing loss.

options.label: D
options.text: They become immune to further damage from loud sounds.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of "filled pauses" such as "um" and "uh" in spoken communication?

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: The danger of silence - Clint Smith

multiple-choice.question: What are the four core principles that Dr. King's teacher has posted in the classroom?

options.label: A
options.text: Read critically, write consciously, speak clearly, and listen carefully

options.label: B
options.text: Read critically, write consciously, speak clearly, and tell your truth

options.label: C
options.text: Read critically, write creatively, speak confidently, and tell your story

options.label: D
options.text: Read critically, write consciously, speak clearly, and share your opinion

multiple-choice.question: What did the teacher give up one year during Lent, and how did it affect him?

options.label: A
options.text: He gave up soda and realized he didn't miss it.

options.label: B
options.text: He gave up speaking and realized he had already given up his voice.

options.label: C
options.text: He gave up social media and realized he had more free time.

options.label: D
options.text: He gave up reading and realized he missed it.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the teacher not speak up when the woman at the fundraising gala made a derogatory comment about his students?

options.label: A
options.text: He was afraid of losing his job.

options.label: B
options.text: He didn't want to offend the woman.

options.label: C
options.text: He thought it was better to just ignore the comment.

options.label: D
options.text: He believed they needed her money more than his students needed their dignity.

multiple-choice.question: What does the teacher mean by "Silence is the residue of fear"?

options.label: A
options.text: That silence is a result of being afraid to speak up.

options.label: B
options.text: That silence is a sign of respect.

options.label: C
options.text: That silence is a form of protest.

options.label: D
options.text: That silence is a way to avoid conflict.

multiple-choice.question: What is the teacher's resolution for the new year, instead of giving something up?

options.label: A
options.text: To live every day as if there were a microphone tucked under his tongue.

options.label: B
options.text: To read more books and write more poetry.

options.label: C
options.text: To speak up only when necessary.

options.label: D
options.text: To listen more and speak less.

options.label: B
options.text: Empathy, Logic, and Communication

options.label: C
options.text: Authenticity, Communication, and Vulnerability

options.label: B
options.text: Authenticity

options.label: C
options.text: Empathy

options.label: D
options.text: Communication

options.text: Try to fit in with others

options.label: B
options.text: Be yourself, even if you represent difference

options.label: C
options.text: Hold back who you are to avoid conflict

options.label: D
options.text: Pay attention to what others want to hear from you

options.label: A
options.text: Encouraging employees to use their cell phones during meetings

options.label: B
options.text: Providing executive education on strategy and leadership

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Promoting employees to positions that outstripped their capability

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the key to achieving greater excellence in organizations?

options.label: B
options.text: Encouraging employees to hold back who they are

options.label: C
options.text: Setting conditions that make it safe for employees to be authentic

options.label: D
options.text: Focusing solely on logic and strategy

title: Why bats don't get sick - Arinjay Banerjee

multiple-choice.question: Why are viruses that infect bats, such as Ebola and SARS, not typically lethal to them?

options.label: A
options.text: Because bats have a highly developed immune system that can easily fight off the viruses.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the viruses have evolved to coexist with bats and not harm them.

options.label: C
options.text: Because bats have a low inflammatory response to viral infections, which prevents tissue damage.

options.label: D
options.text: Because bats are immune to all viral infections.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the way bats respond to damaged DNA in their cells?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a highly active immune response that attacks and removes damaged DNA.

options.label: B
options.text: They have a dampened immune response that ignores damaged DNA.

options.label: C
options.text: They have a specialized repair mechanism that fixes damaged DNA.

options.label: D
options.text: They have a high rate of cell division that replaces damaged cells.

multiple-choice.question: According to a 2013 study, what may contribute to bats' long lifespans?

options.label: A
options.text: Their high metabolic rate.

options.label: B
options.text: Their efficient repair genes that counteract DNA damage.

options.label: C
options.text: Their ability to fly long distances.

options.label: D
options.text: Their diet rich in fruits and insects.

multiple-choice.question: What is a major threat to bat populations worldwide?

options.label: A
options.text: Viral infections such as Ebola and SARS.

options.label: B
options.text: Bacterial infections such as tuberculosis.

options.label: C
options.text: Fungal infections such as white-nose syndrome.

options.label: D
options.text: Habitat destruction and climate change.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to preserve bat populations and their ecosystems?

options.label: A
options.text: Because bats are a food source for other animals.

options.label: B
options.text: Because bats help with pollination and seed dispersal.

options.label: C
options.text: Because bats consume pests and insects that can harm crops.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.
